column11: Review Text

column8: Scenic highlight, zero tourists, insider tip from Tissa
column11: My highlight in Tissa, but you need a jeep there, as elephant encounters occur on the gravel road. Go down into the valley behind the white stupa and then up the small path to the second on the rock opposite...a real Indiana Joes feeling. You climb up through rock gates, narrow paths and up from the stupa a sensational view into the bizarre landscape, speckled with large grant rocks. There is no human here, the few locals only go up to the 1. Stupa.

We visited the rock temple late afternoon/evening with a guide. It is a fantastic place, particularly if it is not busy, we pretty much had the place to ourselves apart from the dogs. monkeys and elephant that wandered in. Beautiful views and fascinating history.

We had a ranger from the Hilton escort us to these wonderful temple.  As the drive is along the edge of Yala National Park, we saw almost as much game (elephant, spotted deer, water buffalo, warthog, deer, jungle fowl, peacock and aligator) has we had on a four hour safari in Yala block 1!  The temple was deserted when we arrived, so were able to spend time with the ranger discussing the history and significance of the site.  One climbs to both temple in sock, so be prepared for this.  The main temple only requires doing stairs, so if you have reasonable mobility it should be doable.  The higher temple involves stairs and also climbing the rock face with a handrail but only thin "steps" cut into the rock.  We were fascinated to hear that elephant walk up and down the stairs: on the last night hike our guide took guests, they came across an elephant making its way down the stairs and they were delayed by over 1 1/2 hours!  The dirt/brown stains on the top of some of the rock overhangs is from elephants making their way under the rock.  A great visit that I recommend.

Loved visiting this, wild baby boar came running up in the car park, no other tourists as quite hard to access   (probably need a jeep or tuk run that you don't mind being slightly bounced around in), bit of a climb so not suited for those who aren't steady on their feet.

column8: you must visit this wonderful rock temple.
column11: beautiful temple inside of the jungle at tissamaharama. you must go with a good guide, because there have lot of wild elephants on the way. this temple has steps to go up in the mountain. the view of the temple is very beautiful. you get a feel its like you staying in a big rock middle of the jungle. i think you must travel for this ancient temple if you staying at tissamaharama.
we have been there after 20 years. still same greenery and really clean temple . i believe who ever visiting kataragama, yala national  park and  kirinda,   those people must visit this place as well

column8: Nice quiet temple in the National Park.
column11: On the way you will see Peacocks, Deers  wild pigs.  Temple parking lot has some pigs waiting for food and Elephants!  We found the worst toilets in this temple ground.  20 Rupees, no tap water at the moment, but very dirty.  Need a good washroom complex.  Rocky Temple area can be hot during day time.  Free entrance for tourists!

You have to climb a very steep stairway which is cut through a rock. When you go up you will be able to see a Dagoba which is said to have been built by King Kawantissa. In addition to this, there are more other small stupas. There is a specific cave temple that consists of beautiful ancient paintings that are believed to belong to the 3rd century BC. The drawings are done on a thin layer of plaster and have used red and yellow colors. It is stated that the rock temple which is a very sophisticated cave consisted of 12000 monks who attained the highest level in mind according to Buddhism.

This ancient Buddhist monastery is said to have been built in the 2nd century BC by King Kavanthissa. Throughout its history of over 2000 years, it has been a key place of worship for Buddhists in the country as well as a point of attraction for tourists. Its recommended to use a SUV drive towards the base of the hill as the road is uneven. The climb is not too hard as there is support built throughout. However due to the weather conditions in the area its recommended to climb during early morning hours or evenings.

My guide and driver took me on part Safari then up to the wonderful Rock Temple. Although itâ€™s basically a dirt track used by the odd bus and local itâ€™s less busy then the main payable Safari park. Itâ€™s basically one road that is in a different zone of the park and there is forest for quite a bit of the trip to the temple. Managed to see a leopard and many birds, monkeys, wild pigs and even a crocodile on a large lake. It would be worth visiting the Temple even if there wasnâ€™t the bonus of the journey to it. The views are wonderful from the Temple of the forest and even Ella in the distance and itâ€™s very well looked after. A beautiful place in the middle of the trees. Go.

We couldn't afford a tour. But we read everything and took a tuktuk for 1600Rs and went from Katharagama to sithulpawwa through a cool old road among the jungle with much flora and fauna. If you need a ride call this driver 0776387229 He is an honest one, didn't raise the amount seeing foreigners. No other public transportation. Sithulpawwa is a beautiful place and it is calm and neat thanks to the chief Monk. He is an animal lover. So no NON-VEG is allowed. And if you harm his wild animals you'll have to pay severe consequences. Even fish must be left in peace. I think animal feel this so even they are at peace.

The journey skirts through an untouristed area of Yala on the way to this rock temple.  Views from here are magnificent and the climb through rocky forest is exhilarating.  If you are lucky you may also spot wild animals along the road: elephants, bears, deer; perhaps even a leopard.  Best attempted in the cool of early morning or late afternoon.

This holy place is easily accessible though the dirt road is a very long and bumpy 14 kilometers. The natural cave is centuries old and now houses an 80-foot reclining buddha statue. The peak temple provides landscape vistas of vast Yala Forest Preserve.

We arranged a safari car from our hotel. The cost was 69 USD. With a TukTuk or snother vehicle if would have been difficult to get there since were driving after heavy rain. On our way we saw lizards, spot deers, different birds including lots of peackocks. When arrived st the temple there were wild boars and an elephant, who were approching the visitors for food. So, we had a mini safari and a visit to the Temple. It has amazing views to explore from the top of the rocks. The climb is difficult, especially, if you go in midday like we did. It's better to choose early morning or a cloudy day.

A sanctuary complex located between two hills in the middle of the wild, overlooked by tourists. In the middle is a small lake full of crocodiles. There is a chance to meet wild elephants during the journey. Incredible experiance.

A group of six of us started early morning from our hotel at Tissa and travelled to Situlpawwa along Kirinda â€“ Situlpawwa road on 12th February 2019.  On either side of the road was thick forest as it runs through Yala National Park.  Lo and behold!  There were three leopards right on the middle of the road, two adults and a cub.  We observed them without getting too close lest they go away.  I also did not have a long lens with me to photograph them as I did not anticipate an encounter with wild animals!  After a while they sauntered into the jungle and we proceeded to Situlpawwa, enjoying the beauty and serenity of the jungle. As we approached Situlpawwa car park area, there hundreds of wild-boars including many cubs â€“ probably used to easy food from pilgrims and visitors.  There is a large parking area and a few shops catering to the pilgrim and devotees who visit here in numbers over weekends and full moon poya days.  There is a police post too at the edge of the parking area. Surrounded by thick jungle, the first to come to view was a stupa atop a hill.  As we came closer, another bigger stupa too became visible.  The smaller stupa atop the taller hill is Kuda (small) Situlpawwa while the larger one, visited by most devotees is called Maha (large) Situlpawwa.  On our ascent to the ancient Buddhist temple Maha Situlpawwa, we came across a troop of monkeys enjoying their breakfast on wild berries.  The path up to the 80-metre-high rock was on a gentle slope along ancient steps carved into rock.  Even those with mild knee problems in our group did not find the ascent tiresome as they could hold on to the handrail by the side.  At the very top is a notice advising pilgrims not only to remove their shoes but also to carry them along to prevent them from being lost to the monkeys who roam around freely. At the top of the rocky summit is the majestic stupa, about 12 metres in diameter, in the shape of a bubble, built by levelling the top of the rock.  We were told that this stupa dates back to 2nd century BCE.  From this vantage point we could see Kuda Situlpawwa, image house, various ruins of buildings and locations of bo-trees as well the pond used for bathing.  As we came down the southern steps built with stone, there were ruins of some small stupas on either side.  The southern steps end at the current temple premises that house an image house, sleeping quarters for the priests as well as an office, where one could make donations for the upkeep of the temple.  Walking further down into a lower area at the eastern side you come to the impressive cave temple.  There lie two Buddha statues one in sleeping position and the other seated.  The sleeping statue is over 8 metres long.  On the far side of the cave house are ruins of two statues with missing hands, housed in a pavilion for protection from the elements. I was absorbed by the symmetry, dignity and grace conveyed by these statues even though they had been damaged.  We were told that these images date back from the 4th century. The whole complex appeared to be well maintained and adequately take care of. We did not attempt to climb the taller hill, the Kuda Situlapawwa, as we were too tired and hungry.  As we walked back from the temple complex, there was an elephant, sauntering on the other side of the steel fence, just a few metres away, seeking food.  Though we were rather uneasy at first, the policemen told us that there was no cause to fear and that he is harmless.  He is apparently used to getting fruits fed by visiting pilgrims. Advise to visitors â€“ Take a bottle of water along with you to quench your thirst. When you remove your shoes at the summit before entering the Stupa enclosure, carry them with you to prevent them from being hi-jacked by monkeys!  You can avoid having to walk on the hot rock if you climb early in the morning.  Entrance is free to all!!

Once being home for 12,000 araths, Sithulpawwa rock monastery (Buddhist temple) holds over 2200 years of a proud history. A hidden jem that forgotten for locals. Not popular amongst  foreign travelers as well. One hour drive from Tissamaharama along the dusty road bordering the yala national park is nothing but a mini Safari. A safari jeep will be the ideal transportation mode to spot few deers, wild boards, peacocks and some little birds.  Watermelon vendors on the sides of the road, are the best options to quench thirst. Magul Maha Vijaraya is another small rock temple come across before the Sithulpawwa which worth a visit. It is known to be one of those places identified as  King Kavantissa and Viharama Devi tied the knot. They were the parents of rebel King, Dutugemunu who wrote a significant chapter in the Sri Lankan history. Surrounded by nature, Sithulpawwa still owns few caves homed for meditating arahaths. Stone in-scripts, remaining of ancient building, small stone stupas which carries ashes of arahaths and many other artifacts are dispersed around the main two temples, turning it in to a valuable archeological site. Top of  the temple has an awesome aerial view of the yala national park. A glimpse of ancient Sri Lanakn history ! A must visit but, make sure to be accompanied someone who is able to tell the whole story.
Ancient temple situated inside Yala national park , Thissamaharama. Bit difficult road with  elephants , but well worth visiting this beautiful Buddhist temple . Better to use an off road or a SUV.

The climb to the top gave wonderful views around the countryside.  Nice statues in the rock cave.  We didn't have a guide so were lacking in knowledge.  Rember this is a temple and appropriate clothing, preferably white, needs to be worn

This ancient Buddhist temple is in a remote area of southern part of Sri Lanka. There had been highly evolved Buddhist monks lived in this area, It is surrounded by jungle. You will absorb lot of spiritual energy to your body when spend some time near the Pagoda.

this is a amazing calm place with full of nature very peaceful the cave with beautiful paints with buddha images we want there late afternoon way back we saw a lots of wild animals snacks and most beautiful leopard crossed the road so so lucky we wear to see all the animals unfortunately we have to pass willd life gate we was bit late they told we are late but they let us out they advice us to not be late 18.00hours great placeã€‚ dont miss this

Ancient Buddhist Monastery built in 2nd century BC by King Kavantissa. The panoramic view of the Ruhunu Sanctuary from the top is breathtaking. A visit in the early morning or evening when the temperature is cooler would be refreshing,  midday visit would be uncomfortable when the hot sun makes the rock surface hot.
Nice Beautiful Place. Ancient Place. This Location You Must See. Dry Zone Rock Views and beautiful Panorama view to the top of the temple. and on the way you can see all the animals.

Well maintained place. Good infrastructure facilities. Religious place with archeological value. Children and adults should be properly look after. Do not feed waild animals. Good place to visit in the morning.

Long Before Buddhism spreads out in the country, this holy place has been a sacred land for centuries. Beautiful spectacular panoramic scenery contains green vegetation and mountains adds a remarkable wonder to this area. Down south oth the country has been famous for many ancient temples and hidden treasures. Definitely a magnificent place to see worship and pay respect!

A temple situatued in the boundaries of Yala, Sithulpawwa is a temple known for the view it offers after the climb. Not to miss is the wildlife you witness in the temple. However, a visit at night cannot be recommended.

Have to visit this temple.  Nice way to climbing up but dont worry not so difficult.  You can also climb up to visit Budha and nice nature and rocks view. Nice temple view. You should be climb up without shoes and with paints no shorts. Amazing place.  Must visit.  They calls this place as jungle temple too.

This is very nice place with historic ruins. Climbing to small sithulpawwa  is not easy task, but very nice view from the top. You may see large Crocodiles even on the way as mentioned in the boards. Loved it..

Temple is located on a part of Yala national park. Sithulpawwa has a great history over 2000 years . History says there were 12000 arahant monks resided here around 1st century. Temple has cave complex and ruins belong to Anuradhapura era.

Seeing that we were the only people visiting the temple around 4-5pm, it has given me enthusiasm to kick start my TripAdvisor account with my first review. We think people are MISSING OUT here, the temple is great to see and walking to the top you have breathtaking views over Yala National Park. We had a close encounter with lots of wildlife (pictured) and unlike the safari there Isn't lots of jeeps with their noisy engines all around you. We stayed and thoroughly enjoyed the Cinnamon Wild hotel who provide excellent tour guides. Gupta was ours and we thought he was great company. Well worth the visit! Highly recommend!

It was around 17 km from Kataragama town. The road was via Yala sanctuary and the road was very dusty, but not that bad. If carefully driven, can go with any vehicle. There also were animals in the sanctuary by the road. Has a large parking area. At noon, it is very hot there. You can climb the rock to its top. This is a historic place. The view was fascinating from the top. The elephants from the sanctuary come here for bathing and eating. Basic washroom facilities and food courts are available.

This place is hidden away in the midst of the Yala National Park and the journey to the temple premises itself was a good experience with bumping into various wild animals through out.. There is historic importance in the temple and the surroundings and the place is frequented by wild animals too.. Built during the time of King Kavanthissa the temple consists of now mostly ruins and subsequent constructions..
We visited here along with our stay in Yala, very good place for you to learn much about buddhism and what it represents.

Enjoyed our visit but as we weren't appropriately advised and we visited with out a guide which was a mistake as the place has a very little signage and it is all in Sinhalese. Guides have to be pre booked. Hope to revisit one day with a well informed guide.

The temple is situated on a huge rock. The place has prehistoric importance. As the temple is situated inside a thick forest, the road to the temple is little difficult and the road is not refurbished with tar. On the way to the temple you may get chances to see peacocks, wild boars and sometimes elephants. The temple is beautiful too. You have to climb the rock to reach the temple. That is a vantage point where you can see a big area from the top. And there is an ancient cave with a statue of Buddha and frescoes.

I wonder how they found this location to build this majestic Stupa. The surrounding is thick jungles with wild Elephants. So the journey it self is quite an interesting one. I loved the Stupa, the shape & the vicinity.

Sithulpawwa situated in the border of Yala forest. You have to go there by a difficult route, but there are wild animals on the way. Mostly, pigs and deer. The top temple is on a rock. Climb there, you can have a scenic view of whole Yala. Do not feel lazy to climb the second mountain to reach Kuda Sithulpawwa. You will be amazed.

Just stand there and take in the vibe of something architecturally stunning given when it was built. The locals come here to offer prayer and thanks and you are more than welcome to be part of the moment.

Beautiful and calm temple located in the middle of Yala National Park. Only 14kms away from Katharagama town. We saw many wild boars and peafowls during the visit to the temple. According to me this one of the must visit places in Katharagama. But you will have to clean your vehicle since the road is dusty.
Make sure you have your legs and shoulders covered, they won't let you in if not. We went to Kataragama and bought 2 sarongs to get in. Both Hindu and Buddist temples on same site.
This is a complex of old Buddhist Temple. A good place to visit.You need about an hour to go around..

Sithulpawwa  is known as a location where thousands of Arhaths lived at one time. According to folklore it is said that a novice monk called Thissa who has reached the state of Arhath lived here and later a stupa was built encasing his remains thus this also has been known as Tissa Thera Chetiya. Sithulpawwa Rajamaha Viharaya contains large number of stupas, cave temples, Buddha statues a stupa house and image houses spread among a large land area. Among these there is a cave temple with ancient paintings thought to be belonging to the 3rd century BC. These drawings have been done on a thin layer of plaster on the rock surface and primarily used red â€“ yellow colours. The main stupa has been built by flattening the top of a rocky mountain. There are two approaches to the stupa. Stone steps have been cut from the south and the north. The boundary walls of the maluwa area have been built using large rocks. Remains of many buildings can be seen on the Northern side of the stupa.

Surrounded by the yala, A very beautiful calm temple 14km away from katharagama. The road to this temple is between the jungle and if you are lucky you will be able to see some animales. By the road side you will find pigs and peakocks. Also this temple you get many things to see.
Deep Inside Yala Sanctuary you can enjoy the fantastic view offered by this rock temple - this was a historic site and used to be a monastery 2000 years ago - a must see

It is extremely hot these days, suggest going in the evening. Amazing view from the top of the temple rock.caved temple where wild animals also survive with human beings. Thank you Saraii village arranging this tour

Sithulpawwa [Yala National Park] Situlpawwa rock temple with a history of over 2000 years is one of the significant Buddhist sites built in the 2nd Century BC. Located deep within the Yala National Park within the Hambantota district in the deep south of Sri Lanka. Sithulpawwa rock temple has a stunning setting. There are two temples perched high atop hard volcanic rock outcrops. Maha Sithulpauwa rock is 400 feet in height. . The dagoba is situated on top of the rock and is reached by a difficult steep climb, aided by steps cut into the rock. The dagoba is believed to have been built by king Kawantissa. It houses an intricate cave complex. The name Sithulpauwa is derived from the word 'Chittalapabbata' which means the hill of the quiet mind. The rock temple was a place of worship for devotees as well as a centre of Buddhist scholarship. It is believed that in ancient times this rock temple once housed a total of 12,000 Arhats or monks who achieved the highest mind level in Buddhism. The life that the Arhats lived in Sithulpawwa was a hard one, with silence and solitude. The rock temple is famous for its early Brahmi script, ruins of the preaching house and the fragments of paintings that can be viewed at the image house. Inside Situlpawwa are a number of gal len (rock caves), dagoba (pagodas), Poya geval (chapter houses), bodhigara, pilimageval and pokunu (ponds).Sithulpawwa rock temple houses an intrincate temple complex. The caves inside have been built to make it suitable for the monks to live. In addition to the main dagoba, a number of small dagobas are found inside Situlpawwa rock temple. The main cave temple walls consists of paintings belonging to Anuradhapura period and this is a significant feature as not many paintings belonging to this period have been found.
Very calm place, awesome landscape, interesting animals around (samba deer, monkeys, bores...) + we saw leopards on the opposite hill ! (recommend binoculars)

Situated in Yala Sanctuary boarder must visit place If you are visiting that part of Sri Lanka. Climbing windy hill to visit Stupa up there is a very nice experience. Usually you can see wild elephant sambar at the temple.
Best place and everyone must watch this. Located in the wildlife sanctuary,  Yala. A short climb because there are two rocks with temples .

This temple is situated near to yala national park. You have to go through the jungle and there are two roads which leads to sithulpawwa. Sithulpawwa temple is an ancient Buddhist place and you can have a good time if you visit here in the evening or early morning. And also you can see lot of wild animals too. If you go there, please make sure to protect the environment and animals. Don't harm to any animal or don't leave garbage there.

Sithulpawwa Rajamaha Viharaya is an ancient Buddhist monastery located in Hambantota District, South Eastern Sri Lanka. Situated 18 km east of the pilgrimage town Katharagama, it is believed to have been built in the 2nd century B.C by king Kavantissa.[1]Sithulpawwa Vihara can be reached by travelling 18 miles along the Tissamaharama-Yodhakandiya road towards the Yala National Park. The name Sithulpawwa is derived from the word "Chiththala Pabbatha", which means the hill of the quiet mind.[1] This ancient monastery with a history over 2200 years, was a place of worship for devotees as well as a center of Buddhist education for Buddhist monks. Paintings of the Anuradhapura era and the ruins of stone Buddha images, Bodhisatva images, Image Houses, Circular Relic Houses are spread throughout the monastery premises. The present chief incumbent of Sithulpawwa Rajamaha Vihara is Ven. Metaramba Hemarathana Nayake Thera

Sithulpawwa temple is an old historic temple located amidst the wildlife sanctuary, closer to Yala. Getting to the top of the Sithul pawwa(rock) would take about 1- 2 hours climb, but the view is breathtaking !

A trip through the Yala park and you get to this temple that is an important pilgrimage centre for Buddhists.  I went there as we like history and like to feel the energy of places and we were happy we made the visit. A short climb up from the card park gets you to the top fr the first stop. Then you can climb down and again take a steeper climb to the neighbouring hill to visit the other temple. There were many Sri Lankan pilgrims there but the place did not feel crowded. The water/pond in-between the two hills, the wandering elephant, the odd dear and just the space around felt really nice.
Go and see not just the temple but the views from The Rock - it is incredible. Remember to give a good donation at reception at the top of the steps.
A remarkable temple of over 2000 years ago, Home to 12000 monks in the first century, This temple is over 400 feet high with wall paintings still visible in the caves.
a bit of a climb to the temple. But very nice view at the top. lots to see if you have time to walk around.
you get to explore the surroundings .. be mindful there is a fair bit of a climb. we did the morning climb which was not too hot.
Good place to go in the evening. When we visiting many local people there. Very quite place if there's no people. Great outing to visit. Big Buddha statue and we saw three elephants on the way.
An antient temple surrounded by ancient but undercover cities. Especially important to stop by for educational purposes. Stunning hilly views.

Drive thru the thick jungle ( Yala NP ) adds a bit of a thrill & scariness to the journey, though road ends with one of the most peaceful & calm ancient Buddhist temple .Best time to visit is during dawn or dusk.
We visited Sithulpawwa Rick temple instead of going on one of the game drives, we stayed at Kulu it was bout 40 mins away, from the top it was great place to see the size and scale of the park

Filled with ancient monuments with a freat history. You need to do bit of hiking to cover the whole place  which would take an hour or more. The drive is through Yala Park. The road from Kataragama is bit difficult however you can enjoy the drive.

It's an amazing drive to this temple. Rich in so much History and architecture..The land is beautiful.the view is breath taking.you could see an arial view of the whole of yala national park.on your way to the temple you will see so much wild life..If your lucky you will spot the wild tusker who visits the temple for food.lovely temple and the climb up is not hard at all.worth every step.loved it

The temple has lot to see and lot of climbing to see all ruins. The road to Sithulpawwa from town was not good few years back and now the roads are good and you will see some animals in their natural habitat on your way to the temple. Worth to visit this ancient temple.
We visited Sithulpawwa during our trip to Yala few days back. This temple is located at a very calm and relaxing environment at Yala park. This is an ideal location to obsetve wildlife as well
History say's more than 5000 enlighted monks was lives this place.this is in side the yala national park ,you can see some of wild animals come and live freely in this temple ,

we visited sithulpawwa. . it is a good experience , be prepared to walk/hike  and although it does not look that different from other historical areas , the drive up to Sithulpawwa does allow you to see many animals, and the views are great along the walk. make sure you where long pants and shirts that over the shoulders for both men and women - or you wont be allowed to go .

Must visit the Situlpawwa temple and the chief incumbent Rev.Metaramba Hemarathana who is bound to inspire any visitor with his love for wild animals and nature. Gemunu the giant tusker is a regular visitor to Rev.Hemarathana who regularly feeds him with fresh fruits and biscuits. Amazing to watch how such a giant of a wild beast obeys the soft command of the small made prelate. Situlpawwa had been the home for 12000 Buddhist monks who achieved a higher state in their meditative journey in the past. Quite often you will come across leopard and elephants on the way to Situlpawwa from Magul Maha Viharaya which was symbolic with Vihara Mahadevi and King Kavantissa in the old history. Absolutely scenic surroundings with hundreds of stone caves which were shelter to meditating monks.
Not lot to see other than forest . Wonderfull experience via forest, from park entrance . Via Thissa will be good . Can go by a car .

I have visited several times to see the temple.Actually not the temple but the animals.Last time my waif and me visit their and had a chance witness around 150 bunch of deer. What.What a moment that was. Always you can sea whld boar near the road.But last time we went to little water gathering place near the road and had wow type experience.At first we saw only few monkeys and two peacocks.After while just appear around 10 bunch of wild boar came lineally and start to playing with mud.After then few deer came to drink water where other set of deer were little far from the place.Then we saw unidentified scavenger type animal.may be a fox or something like that

You can drive to temple by yourself on the same and similar jungle trails as Yala block I. We encountered quite a few animals and a pretty curious elephant on the way! The temple and the rocks themselves are nice and easy hikes and you get to understand a lot about pre-historical significance of the area

A Buddhist temple with a very long history which may be able to backdated until BC, situated in the middle of the jungle. if you have time and courage you can visit the both "dagoba". if you visited the one named "kuda sithul pawwa" you can get a precious, dramatic view of the yala national park.

This was a side-trip that we opted to do.  We went close to sunset and had a magnificent view over Yala national park.  It helped put the park into context for us, as so often you are in a jeep deep in park which is mostly flat.  Very few tourists and going after normal hours there were very few people here at all. We also saw close to 100 mccaw toucan birds fly home to trees just below the temple.  Again, this was an unexpected highlight of our Yala adventure trip. You do have to climb some stairs and part of the way up is without shoes (religious obligation requirement)
The site is nice. The summit has a nice view all around as far as the eye can see. Roads however are bad and extremely dusty. Avoid going there when the climate is hot because you WILL get baked.
roads are good and you will see some animals in their natural habitat on your way to the temple. Worth to visit this ancient temple.
Long drive from Yala but worth it. Travel in the early morning to see the sun rise, or late afternoon to see the sunset and wild animal.
It is extremely hot these days, suggest going in the evening. Amazing view from the top of the temple rock.
caved temple where wild animals also survive with human beings. During my life time it is the first visit to monastery with my family

I love this place and when ever I go to Katharagama I never forget to go there. It's a must visit place if you are traveling in that region. Build on the rock and still the old building architecture can be seen. Very nice place in the Yala national park. I love the way that we have to travel to reach Sithul pawwa. If you go early morning lot of animals can be seen. Road is not very comfortable but worth while going.
Sithulpawwa rock temple is historically significant and identified as one of the greatest of Buddhist scholarship.
We went to Jetwing Yala and on the way back to Colombo we were visited the temple. road was not so good but worth for visiting this temple. As a Buddhist must visit this.

Sithulpawwa Situated in Kirinda in Hambanthota District, Sithulpawwa Rajamaha Viharaya has also being called Chiththala Pabbatha in the ancient texts. Stone Inscriptions has identified this location as â€œChithala Paawatha Veheraâ€. This temple complex is attributed to King Kavanthissa who ruled southern area of the country. Sithulpawwa  is known as a location where thousands of Arhaths lived at one time. According to folklore it is said that a novice monk called Thissa who has reached the state of Arhath lived here and later a stupa was built encasing his remains thus this also has been known as Tissa Thera Chetiya. Sithulpawwa Stupa Sithulpawwa Rajamaha Viharaya contains large number of stupas, cave temples, Buddha statues a stupa house and image houses spread among a large land area. Among these there is a cave temple with ancient paintings thought to be belonging to the 3rd century BC. These drawings have been done on a thin layer of plaster on the rock surface and primarily used red â€“ yellow colours. The main stupa has been built by flattening the top of a rocky mountain. There are two approaches to the stupa. Stone steps have been cut from the south and the north. The boundary walls of the maluwa area have been built using large rocks. Remains of many buildings can be seen on the Northern side of the stupa. sithulpawwa rajamaha viharaya In addition to the main Sithulpawwa stupa another hill called the â€˜Small Sithulpawwa â€™ also contains similar stupa and buildings. Stupas have been built on each peak of this rocky mountain range and all these have been built in the Pre Christian Era. A large amount of valuable items has been found from the excavations on this site including an exclusively made image of goddess Thara in a seating position and many Buddha statues. Two Statues of the Awalokeswara Bodisattva can be seen on the main cave temple. One of these is dressed as a royal and the other is plainly dressed as a sage. A large number of rock inscriptions have been found throughout the vihara complex. All these belong to the pre Christian era and some letters in these inscriptions show localization effects compared to Inscriptions in the Anuradhapura in the same era. Some of these pre Christian inscriptions mentions two of the â€˜Dasamaha Yodhayanâ€™ (the ten giants in the Army of King Dutugemunu) called Nandimithra and Welusumana. Another giant of the â€˜Dasamaha Yodhayanâ€™ Pussadeva is also said to be from this area. According to the great chroricle Mahawansa, King Vasaba has built 10 stupas in the Sithulpqwwa (then Chiththal Pabbatha) According to stone inscriptions King Mahallaka Naga (134-146) has built stupas and donated land to the temple and the regional King Dappula of Rohana has donated the village called Gonmitigma in 659 AC. Today this village has been identified as Gonagala.

We took a tuktuk ride from kataragama to the temple (1300rs two-way). It's a fun drive on dirtroads, and to get there you go through a back entrance of yala park. The good thing is that you don't have to pay any entrance fees for this and we saw lots of wildlife during the drive. the temple itself is nice and we were the only foreigners.

A trip through the Yala park and you get to this temple that is an important pilgrimage centre for Buddhists. My wife and I went there as we like history and like to feel the energy of places and we were happy we made the visit. A short climb up from the card park gets you to the top fr the first stop. Then you can climb down and again take a steeper climb to the neighbouring hill to visit the other temple. There were many Sri Lankan pilgrims there but the place did not feel crowded. The water/pond in-between the two hills, the wandering elephant, the odd dear and just the space around felt really nice.

As a buddhist, this was a place I wanted to visit for some time but could not do so because of the distance. However, when I went to Yala in August 2014, I managed to visit this temple. There is also another smaller temple on top of the adjoining hill which we managed to climb & visit as well. The temple is located in a historic site and there are many ruins & caves to explore. The view of the surrounding area was breathtaking since the temple is located at inside the Yala reserve. Since it is religious site, do be mindful of your dress and observe silence when visiting the area. There was also an elephant (tusker) who was roaming in the parking area!!! The place can be quite windy at time. The approach road was a gravel road and hence was quite dusty. On the way to the temple we saw peacocks, rabbits, an elephant, deer and even a bear.

Ruins of an ancient Buddhist rock temple. Lot to see more than anything at Kathargama. There is a small museum and store selling books about the temple and also about Buddhism. Ample parking. Ride into the Yala national park to reach this temple is exiting. Highly recommended.

The temple has lot to see and lot of climbing to see all ruins. The road to Sithulpawwa from town was not good few years back and now the roads are good and you will see some animals in their natural habitat on your way to the temple. Worth to visit this ancient temple.

Very beautiful and ancient temple build on around 300 BC. King "Mahanaga" was the kind of "Magama" kingdom, so this ancient temple was belong to Magama kingdom. This monastery is covered by massive rocks and very big jungle. its has very quite environment and the only sound we can hear is birds singing sounds, some times the monkeys'. "Sithulpawwa", meaning of this name is, "mind admirable mountain". Yes it is the truth. because when we get in there we can feel the calmness. for meditation, this is a best place. The road to situlpawwa is little bit difficult, because some of places has lots of hole on the road and the dust. also on the way to situlpawwa monastery can see lots of many many birds, deers, monkeys. very interesting 35Km s from Tissamaharama.

This is another beautiful temple which requires a little bit of climbing. At the top of the rock is the Temple & you can see lots of monkeys in the area which is a very serene sight, but keep your distance from them since not all of them are very nice. Once you're at the top of the rock you can see the surrounding area. There're some archaeological sites in the immediate vicinity as well. There's another temple which requires a jungle trek and another hike to reach this. Unfortunately the Sun was going down & therefore we couldn't go the second temple.

The access road up to the temple is been done up now and has made a major difference to getting there. (its 20+ km) from the main road and was quite bad before. If you are in the yala area its a good place to visit and if you are retuning from a morning safari in the national park there is a short cut , turning right soon after the park entrance that will bring you half way to the temple. This is aplace of bot religious and historic significance to the people of Sri Lanka and hence if you have any alcohol in your vehicle, you should leave it at the check point entrance and they will return it on your way back. alos note no shorts are allowed and you clothes must cover below the knee. They are quite strick about it.
